translated: The Parivāra🔽The Collection of Stanzas
The training rules laid down in the city of Sāvatthī
“Having put your robe over one shoulder,🔽And having raised your joined palms,
You stand like one who is exhausted.
Why have you come here?”
“The training rules laid down in the two Monastic Laws,

original: Uddesaṁ āgacchanti uposathesu;🔽Kati te sikkhāpadā honti,
analyzed: uddesam āgacchanti uposathesu  kati te sikkhāpadāḥ honti
translated: Which are recited at the observance-day ceremony,🔽How many of them are there?
In how many cities were they laid down?”
“Your question is well-phrased,
And you ask in accordance with what is logical.
I will answer you,
So that you may be skilled in this.”
“The training rules laid down in the two Monastic Laws,
Which are recited at the observance-day ceremony,
There are one hundred and fifty-six of them,
Laid down in seven cities.”
“In which seven cities were they laid down?
Please explain this to me.
Having listened to your words,
We will practice for our welfare.”
“In Vesālī, Rājagaha,
Sāvatthī, and Āḷavī,
Kosambī, the Sakyan town,
And the Bhaggas’ town.”
“How many were laid down in Vesālī,
how many in Rājagaha?
How many in Sāvatthī,
how many in Āḷavī?”
“How many were laid down in Kosambī,
how many in the Sakyan lands?
How many in the Bhaggava lands?
Please tell me this when asked.”
“Ten were laid down in Vesālī,
twenty-one in Rājagaha;
sixty-three hundred
were all laid down in Sāvatthī.
Six were laid down in Āḷavī,
eight in Kosambī;
eight in the Sakyan lands
and three in the Bhaggava lands.
Those laid down in Vesālī,
listen to them as they really are:
Intercourse, and more than that,
and black and beyond that.
True, and eating at the wrong time,
and tooth cleaner, and naked;
And abusing nuns:
these ten were laid down in Vesālī.
Those laid down in Rājagaha,
listen to them as they really are:
Stealing, in Rājagaha,

analyzed: dve anuddhasanā dve api ca bhedā
translated: two instigations, and two schisms.
Inner robe, silver, thread,
And with complaining, the offense entailing confession that is a lump of boiled rice;🔽Eating in a group, at the wrong time,

analyzed: gaṇa bhojanam vikāle ca  cārittam nahānam ūnavīsati
translated: And conduct, bathing, less than twenty.
Having given a robe, they urged,
These were laid down in Rājagaha;
The practice of climbing a tree there,
And with giving consent, twenty-one.
Those laid down in Sāvatthī,
Listen to them as they truly are:
There are four offenses entailing expulsion,
And there are sixteen offenses entailing suspension.
And there are two undetermined offenses,
And twenty-four offenses entailing relinquishment;
And fifty-six offenses,
Are said to be minor offenses.
And there are ten offenses of wrong conduct,
And seventy-two training rules;
And three hundred and six,
All were laid down in Sāvatthī.
Those laid down in Āḷavī,
Listen to them as they truly are:
A hut, silk bed,
And digging, and going, and a deity;
And they sprinkle water containing living beings,
These six were laid down in Āḷavī.
Those laid down in Kosambī,
Listen to them as they truly are:
The Great Monastery, difficult to correct,
Another gate, and liquor;
Disrespect, a legitimate legal procedure,
And the eighth is with milk.
Those that were laid down in the Sakyan country,
Listen to them as they truly are:

analyzed: eḷaka lomāni patto ca  ovādaḥ ca iva bhesajja
translated: Wool, a bowl,🔽And advice, and medicine.
A needle, and the wilderness,
And the eight in the Kāpila country;
Purification with water, and advice,
Are recited in the nuns’ rules.
Those that were laid down in the Bhaggava country,
Listen to them as they truly are:
They store, and they sew,
With meat, and with sesame seeds.
There are four offenses entailing expulsion,
And there are offenses entailing suspension;
There are seven offenses entailing relinquishment,

original: aṭṭha dvattiṁsa khuddakā.🔽Dve gārayhā tayo sekkhā,
analyzed: aṭṭha dvattisa khuddakā  dve gārayhā tayo sekkhā
translated: And eight and thirty minor rules.🔽Two offenses entailing confession, and three for a trainee,
And fifty-three training rules;
They were laid down in six towns
By the Buddha, the Kinsman of the Sun.
There are six hundred and three,
All of them were laid down in Sāvatthī
By the compassionate Buddha,
The famous Gotama.”
The four kinds of failure

analyzed: yam tam pucchimha a kittayi naḥ
translated: “You have answered what I asked,
And it is not otherwise.

analyzed: aññam tam pucchāmi tat iṅgha brūhi
translated: I ask you another question, so please tell me this:
Heavy and light, with and without remainder,
Without remainder, grave and minor,
And those that are the third offense.
Common and uncommon,
And the kinds of settling by which they are settled—
Please explain all of these,
And we will listen to your words.”
“The heavy ones are thirty-one,
And eight of them are without remainder.
Those that are heavy are grave,
And those that are grave are failure in morality.
The offenses entailing expulsion and the offenses entailing suspension

analyzed: sīla vipatti iti vuccati  thullaccayam pācittiyā  pāṭidesanīyam dukkaṭa
translated: Are called failure in morality.🔽The serious offenses, the offenses entailing confession,🔽The offenses entailing acknowledgment, and the offenses of wrong conduct;
And the wrong speech,🔽And the one who abuses with the aim of causing laughter—

analyzed: ayam sā ācāra vipatti sammatā  viparīta diṭṭhim gaṇhanti  asat dhammehi purakkhatā
translated: This is considered failure in conduct.🔽They hold a view that is contrary to the Teaching,🔽And they are led by what is not the true Teaching;
They misrepresent the Buddha,
The unwise, covered by delusion,
This is considered failure in view.

original: Ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā pāpiccho icchāpakato asantaṁ abhūtaṁ uttarimanussadhammaṁ ullapati,
analyzed: ājīva hetu ājīva kāraṇā pāpicchaḥ icchā apakataḥ asantam abhūtam uttari manussa dhammam ullapati

translated: for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he engages in matchmaking, for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he says, ‘The monk who lives in your dwelling is a perfected one,’ for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fine foods that he has asked for himself, for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fine foods that he has asked for himself, for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fresh or cooked food that he has not received from anyone,🔽

for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he engages in matchmaking; for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he says, ‘The monk who’s staying in your dwelling is a perfected one’; for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fresh or cooked food after personally receiving the invitation; for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fresh or cooked food after personally requesting it; for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fresh or cooked food after personally requesting it; for the sake of livelihood, for the sake of a living, he eats fresh or cooked food after personally requesting it.
This is the failure in livelihood that is acknowledged.
Eleven on the third time,
Listen to them as they truly are:
One who associates with one who has been ejected,
Eight on the third time,

analyzed: ariṭṭhaḥ caṇḍakāḷī ca  ime te yāvatatiyakā
translated: Ariṭṭha and Caṇḍakāḷī,🔽These are the ones on the third time.”
Cutting, etc.
“How many things are to be cut?🔽How many things are to be split?
How many things are to be torn?
How many things are not offenses entailing acknowledgment?🔽How many things are agreed upon by the Sangha?
How many things are proper?
How many things are at the most?
How many things are known to be laid down?
by the Buddha, the Kinsman of the Sun.”
“There are six that are cuttable.🔽There is one that is breakable.
There is one that is to be untied.
There are four that are not to be confessed by another.
There are four agreements with the monks.
There are seven proper behaviors.
There are fourteen maximums.
Sixteen are known to be laid down,
by the Buddha, the Kinsman of the Sun.”
. The shared and so on

training rules for the monks.
They are recited at the observance-day ceremony.
There are three hundred and four
training rules for the nuns,
which are recited at the observance-day ceremony.
Forty-six of the monks’ rules
are not shared with the nuns.
One hundred and thirty of the nuns’ rules
are not shared with the monks.

There are four rules entailing expulsion,
There are thirteen offenses entailing suspension,
and two undetermined offenses.

translated: And one is settled by one.”🔽The offenses entailing expulsion, etc.
“As for what was said about the offense entailing expulsion,
Listen to that as it really is:
One is expelled, fallen, defeated,
And excluded from the true Teaching.
There’s no living together with them,
And that’s why it’s called that.”
“As for what was said about the offense entailing suspension,
Listen to that as it really is:

analyzed: saṅghaḥ uva deti parivāsa  mūlāya paṭikassati
translated: The Sangha gives probation,🔽Sends back to the beginning,
Gives the trial period, rehabilitates,
And that’s why it’s called that.”
“As for what was said about the undetermined offense,

analyzed: tam suṇohi yathātatha  a niyataḥ na niyataḥ
translated: Listen to that as it really is:🔽It’s undetermined, not determined,
And it’s not a fixed rule.
It’s one of three kinds of grounds,
And that’s why it’s called undetermined.”
“As for what was said about the serious offense,
Listen to that as it really is:
One confesses in the presence of one person,
And the other person accepts it.
There is no offense equal to that,
and that is why it is called a pārājika.
“For which you are expelled,”
listen to that as it really was:
In the midst of the Sangha, in the midst of a group,
and alone with one person,
having confessed, one should reveal it,
and that is why it is called a pārājika.
“For which you are reproved,”
listen to that as it really was:
One destroys wholesome qualities
and is in conflict with the noble ones.
It is a state of confusion of mind,
and that is why it is called a pārājika.
“For which you should recognize an offense,”
listen to that as it really was:

analyzed: bhikkhu aññātako santaḥ  kicchā laddhāya bhojana

is blameworthy in the Dispensation of the One of Good Guidance.
“What is called ‘wrong conduct’
listen to that as it really is:
What is faulty, what is failed,
and what is wrong conduct.
Whatever evil a person does,
whether in public or in private,
they announce it as ‘wrong conduct’;
that is why it is called that.
“What is called ‘wrong speech’
listen to that as it really is:🔽Wrong speech, badly spoken,
and a word that is defiled,
and what the wise criticize,
that is why it is called that.
“What is called ‘training’
listen to that as it really is:
For one in training, for one training,
for one following the straight path,
This is the beginning and the practice,
The face is restraint of the mind.
There is no training like this,
Therefore it is said thus.
The covered one is rained on,
The open one is not rained on;
Therefore open the covered one,
Thus it is not rained on.

analyzed: gati migānam pavana  ākāsaḥ pakkhinam gati
translated: The forest is the way of deer,🔽The sky is the way of birds;
Destruction is the way of things,
Nibbana is the way of the Worthy One.
The Collection of Stanzas is finished.🔽The summary:
In the city of the seven treasures,
And the four kinds of misfortune;
For monks and nuns,
Shared and unshared;
For the support of the Dispensation,🔽This is the Collection of Stanzas.
The Collection of Stanzas is finished.
